title: 106_hr1942
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that free trade agreements improve income and prosperity by increasing competition, reducing costs, and creating new opportunities for trade and investment. APEC member economies aim for "free and open trade" by 2020 for developing countries and 2010 for developed countries, promoting economic growth and stability by reducing tariffs and nontariff barriers. Continued economic growth and stability in the Pacific Rim region are crucial for the United States, especially in light of the financial crisis in Asia. The disruption in trade patterns from 1989-1997 highlights the importance of reducing trade barriers and fostering opportunities for investment. The disruption in trade patterns from 1989-1997 emphasizes the need to reduce trade barriers and promote investment opportunities. Free trade agreement negotiations offer leverage to open markets for US goods and services, especially during challenging economic times. Strengthening ties with allies like New Zealand, Australia, and Singapore, who support trade liberalization, is crucial for economic growth in the Pacific Rim region. Building closer ties and coordinating with countries like Australia and Singapore, who are long-time allies of the United States in promoting economic growth through trade liberalization, will be beneficial as trade negotiations proceed in the Asia-Pacific region. The United States must continue to aggressively pursue short- and long-term trade and investment negotiations to advance its interests in the region. Bilateral trade agreement negotiations have been shown to positively impact multilateral and regional trade talks. The United States aims to promote its interests in the Asia-Pacific region through aggressive trade and investment negotiations. Bilateral trade talks can positively influence multilateral and regional trade negotiations by expanding common areas of agreement. Resolving trade disputes with Pacific Rim countries through mutually agreed-upon disciplines is more effective than issue-by-issue confrontations under trade remedy laws. Trade and investment disputes between the United States and Pacific Rim countries can be better resolved through mutually agreed-upon disciplines and dispute settlement mechanisms in free trade agreements. These agreements will enhance cooperation, market access, and understanding for US firms in Pacific Rim markets, stabilizing the bilateral trade balance. Free trade agreements improve market access for US firms in Pacific Rim markets, stabilizing bilateral trade balances. The United States trade policy with eligible Pacific Rim countries is outlined in Section 2. The United States aims to eliminate tariff and nontariff barriers through bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries. Nontariff barriers include regulatory obstacles, lack of protection for intellectual property, and arbitrary standards. The United States aims to eliminate nontariff barriers such as arbitrary standards, intellectual property protection issues, and unfair trade practices. SEC. 3. PRENEGOTIATION CONSULTATIONS. Within 60 days of enacting the Act, the President will consult with eligible Pacific Rim countries. If feasible, a ministerial meeting will be requested within 60 days to discuss free trade agreement negotiations. The US International Trade Commission will provide advice within 6 months after each ministerial meeting. The US International Trade Commission will advise the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment for products of eligible Pacific Rim countries on US industries and consumers. SEC. 4. MINISTERIAL MEETING RECOMMENDATIONS. The President recommends establishing a council of public and private sector officials to review aspects of the existing bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement. The council analyzes trade practices, customs laws, economic data, and disputes, issuing a report within 6 months on the overall relationship and prospects. The council will review trade practices, customs laws, economic data, and disputes to issue a report on the overall bilateral relationship and prospects for a successful negotiation of a free trade agreement within 6 months. The council will review trade practices, customs laws, economic data, and disputes to issue a report on the overall bilateral relationship and prospects for a successful negotiation of a free trade agreement within 6 months. Presidential determination on feasibility and desirability of negotiating free trade agreements with eligible countries. The President will make a determination on the feasibility and desirability of starting formal negotiations for a free trade agreement with a Pacific Rim country or countries, based on reports from bilateral councils. The determination will be submitted to the Senate Committee on Finance and the House Committee on Ways and Means. The President will consider factors like WTO membership, interest in bilateral trade agreements, and trade liberalization when determining the feasibility of a free trade area with a Pacific Rim country. The Pacific Rim country has pursued trade liberalization and economic reforms to achieve an open economy. They have shown support for US trade policy objectives and are actively involved in World Trade Organization preparations. The Pacific Rim country supports US trade policy objectives and is actively involved in World Trade Organization preparations, demonstrating commitment to an accelerated negotiating round. They are working to eliminate export requirements, harmonize standards, increase economic opportunities for small businesses, remove trade barriers in services, and provide national treatment for foreign direct investment. The country in question supports US trade policy objectives, actively participates in WTO preparations, and is committed to accelerating negotiations. They are focused on deregulation to benefit small- and medium-sized businesses, eliminating trade barriers in services, providing national treatment for foreign direct investment, and resolving trade disputes with the US. Their market for US products and services will greatly benefit from improved dispute settlement mechanisms. The country in question is focused on deregulation, eliminating trade barriers, providing national treatment for foreign direct investment, and resolving trade disputes with the US. Their market for US products and services will benefit from improved dispute settlement mechanisms and the elimination of tariff and nontariff barriers. The President must consult regularly with specific congressional committees regarding the implementation of the Act. The Act defines eligible Pacific Rim countries as WTO members and APEC economies.
